definition: Wu Tingfang (1842-1922), diplomat and lawyer
surname Wu
squad of five soldiers/to associate with/five (banker's anti-fraud numeral)
palace courtyard
fragrant

sentences.english: Part two analyzes the basic principles of Wu"s diplomatic thoughts."
sentences.chinese: 第二部分分析伍廷芳外交思想的基本原则。

sentences.english: Part one expounds the basic targets of Wu"s diplomatic thoughts."
sentences.chinese: 第一部分阐述伍廷芳外交思想的根本目标。

sentences.english: Wu had importance influence on the Sino-US relations during the later Qing period.
sentences.chinese: 伍廷芳对晚清时期的中美关系产生了重要影响。

sentences.english: Part four probes in the influence and limits of Wu"s diplomatic thoughts."
sentences.chinese: 第四部分探讨了伍廷芳外交思想的影响和局限。

sentences.english: The diplomatic strategy of balance of power was adopted by Wu.
sentences.chinese: 均势外交是伍廷芳采取的外交策略。

sentences.english: Third, the key factor, Wu had changed his political attitude.
sentences.chinese: 伍廷芳政治态度的转变则是其出任的关键。

definition: Tang Shaoyi (1862-1939), politician and diplomat
Lu Zhengxiang (1871-1949), Chinese diplomat and Catholic monk
the Qing dynasty equivalent of the Foreign Office
Li Hung-chang or Li Hongzhang (1823-1901), Qing dynasty general, politician and diplomat
Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Qing Dynasty
the Warlord government of Northern China that developed from the Qing Beiyang army 北洋軍閥|北洋军阀 after the Xinhai revolution of 1911
Zhang Zhidong (1837-1909), prominent politician in late Qing
Zhang Yinhuan (1837-1900), late Qing politician and senior Chinese diplomat
Song Jiaoren (1882-1913), politician of the revolutionary party involved in the 1911 Xinhai revolution, murdered in Shanghai in 1913
Xu Shichang (1855-1939), politician associated with the Northern Warlords, president of China in 1921
ITŌ Hirobumi (1841-1909), Japanese Meiji restoration politician, prime minister on four occasions, influential in Japanese expansionism in Korea, assassinated in Harbin
Duan Qirui (1864-1936), commander of Beiyang Army under Yuan Shikai, then politician and powerful warlord
Zhang Shizhao (1881-1973), revolutionary journalist in Shanghai, then established writer
Cang Jize or Tseng Chi-tse (1839-1890), pioneer diplomat of late Qing, serve as imperial commissioner (ambassador) to UK, France and Russia
Zhang Taiyan (1869-1936), scholar, journalist, revolutionary and leading intellectual around the time of the Xinhai revolution
Kang Youwei (1858-1927), Confucian intellectual, educator and would-be reformer, main leader of the failed reform movement of 1898
